It's great that you're excited to get back into swimming!

When it comes to incorporating swimming into your training routine, it's essential to find a balance that works for you. Aim to swim 2-3 times per week, with at least one day of rest in between. This will allow your body to recover and adapt to the new demands of swimming.

However, it's also important to listen to your body and not push yourself too hard, especially if you're just getting back into swimming. You can start with 1-2 times per week and gradually increase the frequency as your body adapts.

Here's a sample swimming schedule to get you started:

* Monday: Swim 20-30 minutes, focusing on endurance and technique
* Wednesday: Rest day or active recovery (e.g., yoga, stretching, or a light run)
* Friday: Swim 20-30 minutes, incorporating intervals and sprints
* Sunday: Rest day or active recovery

Remember, this is just a sample schedule, and you should adjust it based on your individual needs and goals. If you're feeling fatigued or experiencing muscle soreness, take an extra day off or modify your swimming routine to make it easier.

In addition to the frequency, pay attention to your body's signals during each swim session. If you're feeling tired or experiencing discomfort, stop and rest. It's better to err on the side of caution and recover than to risk injury.

As you get more comfortable with swimming, you can experiment with different workouts, such as:

* Endurance swims: Focus on swimming at a moderate pace for an extended period (20-30 minutes)
* Interval swims: Alternate between high-intensity sprints and active recovery
* Strength swims: Incorporate strength training exercises, such as kicking drills or pull-ups, to target specific muscle groups
* Active recovery swims: Swim at a leisurely pace, focusing on technique and relaxation

Remember to mix it up and have fun with it!

How does this sound? Are you ready to get started with your swimming routine?
